message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emergent phases of ecological diversity and dynamics mapped in microcosms
Paper Abstract: From tropical forests to gut microbiomes, ecological communities host notably high numbers of coexisting species. Beyond high biodiversity, communities exhibit a range of complex dynamics that are difficult to explain under a unified framework. Using bacterial microcosms, we performed a direct test of theory predicting that simple community-level features dictate emergent behaviors of communities. As either the number of species or the strength of interactions increases, we show that microbial ecosystems transition between three distinct dynamical phases, from a stable equilibrium in which all species coexist to partial coexistence to emergence of persistent fluctuations in species abundances, in the order predicted by theory. Under fixed conditions, high biodiversity and fluctuations reinforce each other. Our results demonstrate predictable emergent patterns of diversity and dynamics in ecological communities.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"Global biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_biodiversity"},{"title":"Biodiversity offsetting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_offsetting"},{"title":"Biodiversity hotspot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot"},{"title":"National Biodiversity Centre (Singapore) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Biodiversity_Centre_(Singapore)"},{"title":"List of biodiversity databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_biodiversity_databases"},{"title":"Global Biodiversity Information Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Biodiversity_Information_Facility"},{"title":"Human Biodiversity Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Biodiversity_Institute"},{"title":"Food biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_biodiversity"},{"title":"Yamuna biodiversity park - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna_biodiversity_park"}]

Here are the search results for "Biodiversity":

## Definition and Overview

Biodiversity is the variability of life on Earth.(no content)It can be measured on various levels, for example, genetic variability, species diversity, ecosystem diversity and phylogenetic diversity.

## Species Numbers

According to estimates, there are approximately 8.7 million terrestrial species and 2.2 million oceanic species. However, estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 2 million to 1 trillion, but most estimates are around 11 million species or fewer.

## Current Crisis

There is significant concern about biodiversity loss. The rate of species loss is greater now than at any time in human history, with extinctions occurring at rates hundreds of times higher than background extinction rates.(no content)The planet has lost 58% of its biodiversity since 1970 according to a 2016 study by the World Wildlife Fund.

## Causes of Biodiversity Loss

The cause of most of the biodiversity loss is human activities that push the planetary boundaries too far, including habitat destruction (for example deforestation) and land use intensification (for example monoculture farming).(no content)Climate change is another threat to global biodiversity, though it is the general habitat destruction (often for expansion of agriculture), not climate change, that is currently the bigger driver of biodiversity loss.

## Biodiversity Hotspots

A biodiversity hotspot is a biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity that is threatened by human habitation.

Web search results for query: "Emergent behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Emergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence"},{"title":"Emergent behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Emergent_behavior&redirect=no"},{"title":"Emergent gameplay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_gameplay"},{"title":"Emergent algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_algorithm"},{"title":"Flocking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behaviour_tree"}]

## Emergent Behavior

Based on the web search results, here's what emergent behavior is:

### Definition

An emergent behavior of a physical system is a qualitative property that can only occur in the limit that the number of microscopic constituents tends to infinity.(no content)In essence an emergent algorithm implements a set of simple building block behaviors that when combined exhibit more complex behaviors.

### Key Characteristics

For many-particle systems, nothing can be calculated exactly from the microscopic equations, and macroscopic systems are characterised by broken symmetry. As a result, these macroscopic systems are described in their own terminology, and have properties that do not depend on many microscopic details.

### Real-World Examples

A classic example is **flocking behavior in birds**: This is an emergent behaviour governed by local rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.

Other examples include:
- Cellular automata, artificial neural networks and swarm intelligence systems (ant colony optimization, bees algorithm, etc.)
- Complex situations in video games, board games, or role-playing games that emerge from the interaction of relatively simple game mechanics.
- In congestion control mechanism, TCP flows can become globally synchronized at bottlenecks. Congestion is possibly an emergent property of the spreading of bottlenecks across a network in high traffic flows which can be considered as a phase transition.

The key insight is that emergent behavior arises from simple local interactions and rules, producing complex patterns and properties that cannot be easily predicted from the individual components alone.

Fisher - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_S._Fisher"}]

Here are the search results for "Phase transitions ecology":

Based on the search results, phase transitions appear in multiple ecological and biological contexts:

**Phase Transitions in Evolutionary Biology:**
Szathmáry pointed out the theory of phase transitions as a potentially useful framework for defining and characterizing major transitions, with this framework proving fruitful in cases such as the transition from prokaryotic to eukaryotic genome, identified as an algorithmic phase transition in the functioning of genes.

**Phase Transitions in Biological Physics:**
Biological physics bridges traditional disciplines and introduces concepts such as stochasticity, phase transitions, and self-organization into the study of life. More broadly, concepts such as phase transitions, self-organization, and stochastic fluctuations, traditionally studied in inanimate systems, have become central for understanding biological systems.

**Phase Transitions in Plant Biology:**
One related concept is vegetative phase change, which is the juvenile-to-adult transition in plants, distinct from the reproductive transition and most prolonged and pronounced in woody species.

**Related Research:**
Physics of life applies methods from mechanics, thermodynamics, statistical physics, and information theory to biological phenomena ranging from molecular assemblies to ecosystems.

The search results suggest that phase transitions are increasingly recognized as important organizing principles in ecological and biological systems, bridging physics and life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Pest insect population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pest_insect_population_dynamics"},{"title":"Population dynamics of fisheries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics_of_fisheries"},{"title":"Population model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_model"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Matrix population models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_population_models"},{"title":"Source–sink dynamics","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source–sink_dynamics"},{"title":"Malthusian growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malthusian_growth_model"},{"title":"Metapopulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metapopulation"},{"title":"León Mario Bedoya - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Mario_Bedoya"}]

I've completed a web search for "Population dynamics." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

## Key Components

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration. More broadly, population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration.

## Historical Foundation

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model. According to Malthus, assuming that the conditions (the environment) remain constant (ceteris paribus), a population will grow (or decline) exponentially.

## Applications

Population dynamics is the basis for understanding changing fishery patterns and issues such as habitat destruction, predation and optimal harvesting rates.(no content)Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation. Population models are also used to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

The search results show that population dynamics is a fundamental field in mathematical biology with widespread applications in conservation, resource management, and disease study.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Species coexistence"

Links: [{"title":"Coexistence theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coexistence_theory"},{"title":"Storage effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storage_effect"},{"title":"Limiting similarity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limiting_similarity"},{"title":"Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_differentiation"},{"title":"Symbiosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbiosis"},{"title":"Durrell Institute of Conservation and Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durrell_Institute_of_Conservation_and_Ecology"},{"title":"Robert H. MacArthur - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_H._MacArthur"},{"title":"Rights of nature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rights_of_nature"},{"title":"Hutchinson's rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hutchinson's_rule"},{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"}]

Here are the search results for "Species coexistence":

## Overview

Coexistence theory explains the stable coexistence of species as an interaction between two opposing forces: fitness differences between species, which should drive the best-adapted species to exclude others within a particular ecological niche, and stabilizing mechanisms, which maintains diversity.

## Key Mechanisms

Two qualitatively different processes can help species to coexist: a reduction in average fitness differences between species or an increase in niche differentiation between species, termed equalizing and stabilizing mechanisms, respectively.

**Stabilizing Mechanisms:** Resource partitioning (a type of niche differentiation) is a stabilizing mechanism because interspecific competition is reduced when different species primarily compete for different resources.

**Storage Effect:** The storage effect is a coexistence mechanism proposed in the ecological theory of species coexistence, which tries to explain how such a wide variety of similar species are able to coexist within the same ecological community or guild. The storage effect was originally proposed in the 1980s to explain coexistence in diverse communities of coral reef fish.

## The Competitive Exclusion Principle

To explain how species coexist, in 1934 Georgii Gause proposed the competitive exclusion principle: species cannot coexist if they have the same ecological niche. Therefore, species must at least have slightly different niches in order to coexist.

The search results provide comprehensive information about the theory and mechanisms that allow different species to coexist in ecological communities.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Microbial ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Microbial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_ecology"},{"title":"International Society for Microbial Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Society_for_Microbial_Ecology"},{"title":"Aquatic Microbial Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquatic_Microbial_Ecology"},{"title":"Microbial loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_loop"},{"title":"Subsurface lithoautotrophic microbial ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsurface_lithoautotrophic_microbial_ecosystem"},{"title":"Microecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microecology"},{"title":"John Klironomos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Klironomos"},{"title":"Sea ice microbial communities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_ice_microbial_communities"},{"title":"Microbiome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiome"},{"title":"Rare biosphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rare_biosphere"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about microbial ecology:

## Definition and Scope

Microbial ecology (or environmental microbiology) is a discipline where the interaction of microorganisms and their environment are studied.(no content)The central themes include cycling of elements in soil and sediments, interactions between microorganisms and plants, animals, and among themselves, and the effect of environmental factors on the growth and activities of microorganisms.

## Historical Development

Microbial ecology started at the end of the nineteenth century with the pioneering work by Martinus W. Beijerinck and Sergei Winogradsky, establishing the science of environmental microbiology and revealing that microorganisms are everywhere in natural environments, often associated with hosts and with beneficial effects on their hosts.

## Key Concepts and Interactions

Microbial ecology studies various types of relationships between organisms:

- **Mutualism**: A relationship between microbial species and other species (example humans) that allows for both sides to benefit.

- **Antagonism**: A type of symbiotic relationship where one species/organism is harmed while the other remains unaffected.

## Applications and Importance

The important role of microorganisms has been recognized by scientists working in many applied fields, including formation and fertility of soil, water supplies, fermentation of food and beverages, food preservation, digestive tract and rumen, and the decay of ancient remains.(no content)The overwhelming majority of microbes are essential for ecosystem functioning and known for beneficial interactions with other microbes and macroorganisms, and maintaining a healthy microbiome is essential for human health and may be a target for new therapeutics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Threatened ecological community - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threatened_ecological_community"},{"title":"Community (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_(ecology)"},{"title":"Biocoenosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biocoenosis"},{"title":"Holistic community - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holistic_community"},{"title":"James Gordon Kelly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Gordon_Kelly"},{"title":"Ecological stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability"},{"title":"Seral community - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seral_community"},{"title":"Ecological succession - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_succession"},{"title":"Ecologically based invasive plant management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecologically_based_invasive_plant_management"},{"title":"Guild (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guild_(ecology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological communities:

## Definition

In ecology, a community is a group or association of populations of two or more different species occupying the same geographical area at the same time, also known as a biocoenosis, biotic community, biological community, ecological community, or life assemblage.

## Key Characteristics

**Species Interactions and Niches:**
Within the community, each species occupies a niche, which determines how it interacts with the environment around it and its role within the community.(no content)By having different niches species are able to coexist through niche partitioning.

**Environmental Factors:**

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Ecological dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Eco-evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eco-evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Theoretical ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_ecology"},{"title":"Ecosystem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Ecosystem model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_model"},{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology"},{"title":"Ecological psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_psychology"},{"title":"Ecosystem ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_ecology"},{"title":"Raymond Lindeman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Lindeman"}]

## Ecological Dynamics: Overview

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological dynamics:

### Definition and Core Concepts

Ecosystems are dynamically interacting systems of organisms, the communities they make up, and the non-living (abiotic) components of their environment.(no content)Ecosystems are dynamic, subject to periodic disturbances and always in the process of recovering from past disturbances.

### Key Aspects of Ecological Dynamics

**Population Dynamics**: Population ecology is a field of ecology that deals with the dynamics of species populations and how these populations interact with the environment, such as birth and death rates, and by immigration and emigration.

**Ecosystem Processes**: Ecosystem processes, such as primary production, nutrient cycling, and niche construction, regulate the flux of energy and matter through an environment.

**Resilience and Resistance**: When disturbances occur, the tendency of an ecosystem to remain close to its equilibrium state, despite that disturbance, is termed its resistance. Additionally, the capacity of a system to absorb disturbance and reorganize while undergoing change so as to retain essentially the same function, structure, identity, and feedbacks is termed its ecological resilience.

### Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics

A related concept is eco-evolutionary dynamics, which refers to the reciprocal effects that ecology and evolution have on each other.(no content)Increasing evidence shows that evolution can also operate on fine time scales simultaneously with ecological processes.

### Modeling Ecological Dynamics

Theoretical ecology is the scientific discipline devoted to the study of ecological systems using theoretical methods such as simple conceptual models, mathematical models, computational simulations, and advanced data analysis.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of the analysis:

## Paper Analysis Summary

**Paper Type**: Contribution

**Key Findings**:
The paper demonstrates predictable emergent phases in microbial ecosystems, validating ecological theory through controlled experiments. It identifies 8 core concepts and methodologies:

### Triples Extracted:

1. **Biodiversity** (concept, uses) - Paper demonstrates how biodiversity patterns emerge and fluctuate
2. **Population ecology** (concept, uses) - Explains species coexistence and abundance patterns
3. **Microbial ecology** (tool, proposes) - Novel bacterial microcosm experimental system
4. **Coexistence theory** (concept, uses) - Tests how species coexist under varying interaction strengths
5. **Population dynamics** (concept, uses) - Demonstrates three distinct dynamical phases
6. **Community (ecology)** (concept, uses) - Studies emergent community properties
7. **Phase transition** (concept, proposes) - Shows transitions between stable, partial, and fluctuating states
8. **Emergence** (concept, proposes) - Complex patterns arising from simple features

**Validation Status**: ✅ All checks passed
- Paper type properly classified as "contribution"
- 8 triples identified and verified
- All Wikipedia URLs validated
- 7 concept entities and 1 tool entity

Sources:
- [Biodiversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity)
- [Population ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology)
- [Microbial ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_ecology)
